awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Collaborative proposal: Engineering increased activity of cutinase toward poly(ethyleneterephthalate) for recycling of plastic
awd_abstract_narration:
The environmental consequences of plastic solid waste are serious. The problem continues to increase as we diversify and expand plastic use and applications. The most significant example of this problem is the rate that plastics are accumulating in oceans, lakes and rivers. The most widely used plastic is polyethylene terephthalate, or PET. PET is used in the manufacture of bottles, polyester fabrics, and food trays. Production levels are estimated to be over 50 million tons per year. This project will attempt to develop an efficient enzyme for the degradation of PET. High school students will be engaged in summer research opportunities. Undergraduate and graduate students will also be involved in the project. These opportunities will help develop a STEM workforce.

Recently, several groups discovered enzymes that catalyze PET hydrolysis under mild conditions. Unfortunately, these enzymes are too slow and too unstable for practical use. Protein engineering to increase their catalytic efficiency is a potential solution.  The project tests a new approach for engineering enzymes to act on insoluble substrates. This approach recognizes that the interaction between an enzyme and an insoluble substrate is complex and involves an extended binding site. The enzyme must pull the chain from the bulk polymer, position the ester group for hydrolysis, and allow the polymer substrate to slide within the binding site for repeated hydrolysis of the chain. Previous attempts to increase the activity of enzymes toward insoluble substrates have met with limited success. The proposed large-area-mutagenesis (LAM) methodology to be implemented in this program is a systematic strategy for engineering enzymes for insoluble synthetic polymer substrates. The approach will: 1) establish the size of the binding region in cutinase that influences its catalytic activity toward PET; 2) optimize the shape of the extended binding region for PET, 3) increase the thermal stability of the enzyme for use above the glass transition temperature of PET, where chain mobility is higher, allowing better access of the enzyme to the polymer substrate. The results of this program will be the engineering of an efficient, stable enzyme with increased catalytic activity of at least 100-fold that may be suitable for commercial PET recycling, which is an essential step to reducing plastic pollution. This project is supported jointly by the Cellular and Biochemical Engineering  Program in CBET/ENG and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in CHE/MPS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Commercial packaging made from poly(ethyleneterephthalate), abbreviated PET, contributes to pollution from discarded plastic in landfills, litter on land and in our oceans. Current recycling of PET yields inferior material that is not as strong and not approved for food applications. Recycling of PET using enzymes has the potential to yield high quality PET, but is currently limited by the slow performance of PET-hydrolyzing enzymes. Our goal was to make these enzymes faster. Our hypothesis was that that multiple substitutions throughout the substrate-binding site would enhance the catalytic activity. Our approach was to create variants of leaf compost cutinase (LCC), the most promising enzyme for the recycling of PET. The variants contained combinations of substitutions that were previously identified as beneficial in PETases. Our polymer chemistry collaborator, Richard Gross's group at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, measured the ability of these variants to cleave PET at different conditions and our computational chemistry collaborator, Silvia Osuna's group at the University of Girona in Spain, modelled how the PET fits in the active site of the variants.

Intellectual Merit. Many of the variants showed increased thermal stability. The ability of the variants to cleave PET was more complex than we expected, so we measured the enzyme behavior under wider range of conditions than other researchers. Some variants hydrolyzed PET quickly, but stopped before all of the PET was hydrolyzed. Other variants worked well at some temperatures, but not at others. To make sense of this complex and unexpected behavior, we formulated a new hypothesis, that the conformations available to the PET were limited on the surface of the solid and that this limited number of conformations limits the overall rate of hydrolysis. This new hypothesis is consistent with the temperature dependence (conformations vary with temperature), the incomplete reaction of some variants (they react with only a subset of available conformations), and the computational modeling (better variants accept a wider range of conformations). This intellectual insight changes the strategy one should use to engineer faster enzymes. One should not engineer enzymes to bind optimal substrate conformations because they occur only rarely. Instead one should engineer enzymes that bind the imperfect substrate conformations that occur frequently. Further, this insight predicts that mixtures of enzyme variants may be better than a single variant.

Broader Impacts. The inability of enzymes to act quickly on insoluble polymers limits progress in several areas. Besides limiting our ability to recycle PET, this problem also limits the use of biomass for manufacturing biofuels and other chemicals. The slow action of cellulase on the insoluble cellulose increases the cost of using biomass. The limitation in these cases is likely the limited conformations available at polymer surfaces. Our research points to a different approach to get around this limit. One can use mixture of enzymes, where each one favors a subset of the available substrate conformations, to increase the rate of hydrolysis. This project contributed to the training of one graduate student who completed his Ph.D. studies in 2023. He attended an international conference and visited our collaborators in Spain. This project funded the training of three undergraduate students in research, which included students from groups underrepresented in science. A Ph.D. student from Brazil (Sao Paulo State University (UNESP) in Araraquarra) Victor Hugo visited for six-weeks to learn molecular biology methods.
